snippet: Bringing a car into the United States that was not originally engineered to meet federal regulations can be a monumental task, but there are detours around some of the regulatory roadblocks.
abstract: Bringing a car into the United States that was not originally engineered to meet federal regulations can be a monumental task, but there are detours around some of the regulatory roadblocks. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: BRINGING a car into the United States that was not originally engineered to meet federal regulations can be a monumental task. Emissions equipment and safety gear may need to be installed, and crash testing may be required. There are detours around some of the regulatory roadblocks, however. The Vehicle Safety Act of 1988, for instance, exempts cars built 25 or more years ago from having to meet Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards in effect when the vehicle was made.
